text: In Formula One, speed is everything, but rebuilding one of the sports' most famous teams is going
to take time.
In 25 I think we have the best driver line up in the grid.
There's good developments on going, there's a butt to it.
Everything's about 26, so 25 will be sacrificed and what that looks like just depends on how
keen others are to take the risks I'm taking.
Williams team principal James Valves has already started taking those risks as he builds
towards 2026, getting a driver to give up his car for his teammate amid season line-up
change and a statement signing of a race-winning star.
Carlos comes with him not just the ability to drive a car quickly but the ability to lead
the team forward.
Hello and welcome to F1 Beyond the Grid with me Tom Clarkson.
James Valves is approaching the end of his second season as Williams team principal and
2024 has been a year of big sometimes controversial calls.
Coming back to Australia when Alex Albon crashed in practice and destroyed his car, James
stood down Logan Sargent so that Alex could race Logan's car.
James then called time on Sargent's F1 career and replaced him with Franco Colopinto, an
F2 race winner, yes, but he only had limited experience of an F1 car.
Risky?
Well no as it turns out, a managerial masterstroke which has already delivered points.
Combined with Albon's impressive performances, it could yet move Williams up the all-important
constructor's standing.
I asked James about all of those decisions and whether Colopinto's performances have
made him rethink signing Carlos' science for 2025.
His answer says everything about how far he thinks Williams can go and that's really
what this entire conversation is about.
I hope you enjoy it.
James, great to have you on the show again.
How are things?
Yeah, they're good.
Yeah, it's good to see you Tom.
Now every time I come to Grove, I'm reminded of this team's heritage.
You've got manzels, car down there in reception.
You've got all the championships and the trophies.
You're in the throes of rebuilding this team.
How close are you to a return to the glory days?
I'm afraid we're still aware away.
We were closer than we were 12 months ago.
That's for sure.
In other words, the direction and travel we're going in is the right one.
But, starting with what you said, I have the same feeling every time I turn up on site.
So, so now and after every day, the legacy washes over you very quickly.
You just feel the power of this organization has and it's brilliant.
So, one of the right track you can now see we're moving forward on the grid.
But a lot of the facilities and infrastructure that we need to have in place will still take
multiple years before they're there.
They are needed first to move forward.
We're not, you know, we are digging right down to foundations.
This isn't a short term solution.
We're going to go right back to people, culture, infrastructure, technology, commercial,
make sure each area is brought back to the fundamentals and then build on top of it.
And that's what I'm still producing at Carb, it's racing in a championship.
I'm reminded of last year's Canadian Grand Prix.
I remember you and I having this exact conversation about facilities and you being 20 years
behind a front running team like Mercedes.
You say you're better than you were 12 months ago, how much better?
How much closer in terms of facilities?
We do have some level of process in place now that captures a structure.
So, it's not, I'm not reliant as much on goodwill of individuals going above and beyond
in order to get past the track.
We have more structure and system and work orders and other lovely things in place.
But actually, I would say at the moment, perhaps productivity may have slowed down a bit because
it will do.
As you go through the process and you find where you're held up, you need to then fix those
blockages in order to get through.
What I also mean by that is with the growth of the team, we're having expertise through
the building and I can see real tangible performance development, especially on the 2026 car.
It's how it's being approached, it's being thought about.
I mean, to start with that.
Already now we're six months into thinking about the car, where do we want all the components
to be laid out?
What are the important elements of it?
Simulation, that's what's being done now for a car that's two years away.
And that's a world of difference for where we have been before.
And so, simulation led and driven by concept and future technologies.
Those aren't tangible items I can do any more than talk to you about at the moment, but
they're real items that you will see the developments of about a year and a half.
Another intangible is mentality.
You mentioned it right at the top.
And to quote Pat Guardiola, you know, winning is a mentality.
What is the mentality of Williams?
First and foremost, we have a responsibility to bring this incredible team back to its
winning ways.
That's how I see it.
And so the mentality here is, there needs to be continuous change.
Doing what we did yesterday, that was great.
That's out of date.
Everything you do tomorrow needs to be in a process improvement on that.
Don't do the same as what you knew before.
Think about what we need to be doing forwards to make steps relative to our competition,
not just match our competition, because we're already behind.
And simply matching them will be behind plus however long it takes us to catch up.
So the mentality we're really doing here is first and foremost is fairly as fine.
Push the boundaries of innovation.
Innovation, by the way, is true change of technology that changes the arena you're working
in or the world.
That's innovation.
It's big.
It's not a small flick that helps you aerodynamically.
It is about really rethinking through the technologies that we're using to develop the car.
It's about the organisation.
And this is an opportunity that doesn't exist up and down the grid.
We have the investment and we have the time.
Let's do this properly.
Do you have the time?
I mean, you say you have the investment.
How much pressure is coming from the shareholders to deliver?
Anyone that spends tens to hundreds of millions will give you pressure.
That's life.
But there's also a very clear agenda around we get it.
We need to do this properly.
So I've set some lines in the ground, 26, 27, 28.
Those are the timelines we need to adhere and work to.
So the pressure is helpful.
It is one that keeps you questioning, are we doing the right thing?
Are we doing the fastest rate possible?
Have we really optimised what's the right spend that we should be doing?
Those are what I would consider helpful pressures.
Unhelpful pressures are go faster.
Do it now.
Because they change the derivative, the goal from where you're aiming to to where you are today.
That's not happening.
So if we throw it forward, well, we've got the last six races,
but also 2025, the regulations are stable over the winter.
We've seen the field converge.
So talking about pressure to perform.
Where do you think Williams can be in 25 under this current rate?
In 25, I think we have the best driver line up in the grid,
which Franco's doing a brilliant job.
What he doesn't have is the experience that Carlos will come with,
but he's doing an outstanding job.
But I think for the perspective of not just driving the car,
but leading the team forward, we'll have the best line up on the grid.
That will help motivate and push us forward.
There's good developments ongoing,
just as a continuation of 24 to 25.
There's a butt to it.
You already know my opinion.
Everything's about 26.
So 25 will be sacrificed.
And what that looks like just depends on how keen others are to take the risks I'm taking.
How much will depend on the opening three races?
If suddenly Williams are up there,
would you continue to develop the 25 car?
Are you about to shake your head at me?
I think you might be.
I still wouldn't, even if you're making a step forward.
I mean, let's talk about if we're leading the championship,
but I think that's an unrealistic goal.
What you actually do it on is you do it based on what's the developments in the pipeline and the winter.
What have you seen over, since you've released the car?
What else is in remaining inside it?
But I think it's unrealistic anyway to expect that.
But even if it was the case, there's far more we can gain by doing things really well for the future.
What would come to the drivers in a minute?
Can we talk a little bit about you as team principal?
You were last on the show June last year.
So it was all still quite new.
You've now firmly got your feet under the table.
What has surprised you about the role of team principal?
I'm not sure anything.
I was so fortunate with Toto.
He really did take me onto his wing and mentored me.
So he also exposed me to what are the positive elements for it and the difficult elements for it.
So not an empowered me to do various elements.
I don't think much has been a surprise.
Just is the quantity.
And it's a different problem to Mercedes.
Mercedes, there you'll really find tuning some small aspects.
Here you'll get spayed in the ground and let's dig in and let's get back to foundations.
So very different sets of problems.
And I don't think anything I would have done anywhere would have prepared me, necessarily, for this.
Because it's enjoyable.
I love every second of it.
But it's a very different set of management skills and leadership skills than I've gathered throughout my career so far.
On to the top of that, what perhaps is hard to prepare for is just how in a space for a moment,
you can go from a fantastic podcast like this.
Do you still download? Do you say download now?
No, I advertise this.
But straight from this into a meeting about some of the issues that we experienced in Singapore,
straight into a meeting about how we're going to do a leadership offside shortly.
What do we need to go within that to just first elements of the business,
commercial going into as well.
So you just bounce between various aspects of the business and you have a minute.
Just to reset yourself, then get straight back into it.
Very little can prepare you for that.
Because former ones be coming more, more specialist within other roles.
And the team principle doesn't have that.
And that's what I enjoy as well about the role.
It's hard to prepare for it.
Are you alone in the fact that you're doing all of those different things?
Are other teams set up differently?
Is Toto doing the same or does he have other people taking some of that load off him?
More a question for him, but when I was stood by,
he obviously has a great team with him all the way through.
There's no doubt about that.
But he still does a tremendous amount.
He's still very much active in the technical meetings as he is active in the debrief,
as he is active with commercial partners.
Different, I would say.
Probably a little bit more commercial-based and I'm a little bit more technical-based,
but that's because that's where relative strengths are found more than anything else.
Where we are here is a little bit different as well,
where I would say we have to grow as a business and have the right strengths with each part.
And we're not there yet. We're growing it.
But that requires a little bit more interaction for myself to make sure we have the strength being built out there.
Is F1 a sport or a business to you?
Sport.
That's why I'm in it.
So the reason why it came so quickly to that is because I'm here to win.
From running this as a business, actually, that's probably not the right way of investing in it.
It can be and it can't be at the same time.
You get big, big growth when you start winning races.
No doubt about that.
But the money required to get there is enormous.
And actually, maybe financially, that's not the best route cause forward.
But I'm in this business to win.
That's why I joined here as well at the same time.
And therefore, you almost have to treat it like a startup.
And anyone that's worked in a startup or a business startup knows that you're not 100% sure what your terms can be.
You believe you're on the right pathway.
But you have to sort of let go of some of the typical constraints you would put business.
That all said and done.
Being clever about how you invest every pound is the right thing to do irrespective of whether it's a sport or a business.
And you mentioned your management influences.
People you've worked with.
Who have been your biggest influences?
I'm thinking you've worked with David Richards.
B-A-R, you've worked with Toto.
Obviously, Ross Braun as well.
Which of those three?
I hope I've taken something from each and every one of them.
So start with D-R.
D-R was just so impressive.
A few words of his would drive the team whichever way he'd like it to go.
Such a strong public speaker.
Leader in every sense, you believe him and want to follow him.
Strength of conviction, strength of speech.
Love that about him.
Ross was very clever at getting the right people in the right room to talk to each other.
And creating a forum where discussion took place.
So he empowered individuals but at the same time.
And that was his strength and I learned a lot from him there.
Toto has a huge business acumen.
Took a business to really a value of very little to a value of probably the best in the grid at the moment.
And I learned to tremendous amount from him there as well.
He's also, and this was Ross and with Toto culturally,
they're very lined and what they believe in in terms of failure and terms of growth,
all those things.
So I hope I've taken a bit from everyone but made it my own along journey.
And would you like skin in the game?
Like two of those?
You know, of course, Toto is now a part shareholder of Mercedes,
Ross, Brawn Grompri back in 2009.
Would it make any difference to you if you had a shareholding in this company?
I think he is not for me to decide that's for my investors to decide it.
But the difference it makes is you feel more attached to what you're doing,
but that's not what I'm driven by.
I'm driven by performance.
I'm fairly rewarded for I am aware I am here.
And what I'm driven by is bringing this team back to the fund.
I hope you're enjoying the chat with James so far.
He's talking about the big decisions that F1 team principles have to make.
And of course Red Bull and V-Carb have just made a very big one,
dropping Daniel Riccardo and bringing back Liam Lawson for the rest of the season.
Christian Horner joins the F1 Nation podcast this week to give us the inside story.
You can find F1 Nation on your podcast app,
but listen to the end of James first,
there's still lots more to come, including his take on Franco-Colopinto's F1 debut.
James, you've got some impressive board members.
I'm thinking Peter Kenyon, X Manchester United, Chelsea,
there's Jensen Bucknell, there's James Matthews, X-Racer himself.
Do you have the support network there for you?
Definitely. I'd also say to that there's Matthew Savage and James.
Matthew Savage and James are the primary board for this part of the organisation.
And I couldn't ask for more.
What I mean by that is if you turn your head to the left, James is there.
That's where he's located. He's four metres from my office,
which means I can on a good day throw something at him.
That interaction with a board member doesn't happen within most organisations,
but it makes us much stronger.
So you instead of waiting for formal meetings four times a year,
you end up talking daily about his problems,
his how we deal with it,
by the way, I'm going to come to you with this investment case,
let's have a think about how we approach that.
Same with Matthew, well, as with him,
or we can't assume what he's arriving in here, I think, tomorrow.
And we'll go through the same sort of discussions.
And it'd be unusual if we're not messaging each other daily.
That's the level of communication.
And I don't think that exists up and down the grid.
So James Matthews is in here most days.
And he's not worked in Formula One before.
Is that a good thing or a bad thing?
Good, because he approaches it from a business sense.
So he's run some very successful businesses himself.
For those that don't know, he was a very good driver in his own right.
Winning championships level, he's good.
British Formula runner, I remember.
Exactly that.
It's worth reminding everyone,
because you can see his head drop when you do that.
It's great fun.
But the reason why I bring that up is what he brings is a knowledge base
of what most sport is about,
combined with the ability and how he's run his own companies to this point.
He has a business acumen that comes with it at the same time.
And that is a huge compliment to what I have as a set of skills at the same time.
Matthew Savage is one multiple organisations at a very high level
and they're very successful.
And he knows how to do that.
So they both bring business sense.
And what I bring to it is more a combination of how you bring the technical together
with the business to make sure we're running this correctly.
And your own racing experience?
Does that help you do you think communicate better with drivers, even with James?
I would say yes, but I've always put out there.
I'm nowhere near the level of the drivers I was in and around.
I wish I was, but I'm enough to hold my own.
And I enjoyed every second of it.
But what it taught me was this.
There's a few things.
When you're in the car, you're incredibly reliant on that single voice
that comes over the radio when you're racing.
And so in my case, I did Asian and Mar and various other endurance racing.
And so you're out there for perhaps up to two hours at a time, perhaps an hour to time.
Your support network appears as one voice in your head.
Just a few words can completely change your approach to what you're doing in the car.
It's very powerful.
Positive and negative.
The next bit is all you can see of the race is what's happening about 500 meters in front of you
or 100 meters behind you.
That's it.
There's nothing more to it.
So you're reliant on the bigger world to help you guide yourself through.
Two other learnings I had for me is that certainly for me,
but actually after speaking to many other drivers, they have the same thing.
When you've appeared at downtime, you lose belief in yourself and you require others to believe in you
in order to push forward.
Or set of results that push you forward as well.
It's surprisingly lonely now there.
So when you're on track, it's surprisingly lonely.
No, this is actually just before you get in.
So this is very personal to me, but when I was racing in Abu Dhabi,
I came from Dubai and Dubai was okay, but it was average.
It wasn't where I wanted it to be.
Came to Abu Dhabi.
And before you get in the car,
you're questioning, am I deserving of this?
Am I in the right place?
Now that changes, for me, at least the minute the engine fires up,
it goes into a very different state.
But what happened there is that the team actually was very good,
positively encouraged me.
And I started setting times that were on par with the other car and then faster.
And that was because you had the force of the team behind you in that situation
where you were a little bit low in your own belief.
You, I'm not going to say you forget how to drive,
but you lose belief that you were the level that you were before.
And sometimes you need the help and the guidance of others in order to push you there.
Now, former one drivers are very different,
but they're up in a world stage against other world champions in the same right.
And they're reliant on everyone around them to make sure that they know
that they are incredible athletes at the very top of their game.
So that's one thing from it.
The final bit that I learned is you feel something,
I had a break failure in Valencia going into term one.
So it's about, you're on the straight at about 200 or something,
250 kilometers an hour.
And I remember it vividly.
So this is in a, what, this is the McLaren.
This is GT3.
No, this one was actually Mercedes.
So the, so the actual brakes itself,
it was mass or ounce of knockoff.
So it wasn't complete failure,
but you had to pump break about four times,
but pumping it twice didn't come back.
So pumped it twice when it's term one,
I just basically dealt with it.
And came on the radio and said basically brakes have failed.
And the engineer came back and went just knock off, pump it four times before you get a
tell whatever time.
And it's hard to describe the motion when you were looking at a wall coming out,
you were at 250 kilometers an hour.
But I was thinking, yeah, I've been that engineer as well,
looking at data going, you have no idea what I've just been through.
And all you're telling me to do is pump the brakes next to two times.
And that's the best description I could ever give as a learning lesson
that you forget what these individuals are going through in the moment.
Never forget that.
They're putting their life on the mind.
That's really what's going on.
And their emotions will ride high.
And just because you see a data trace that tells you it's going to be okay,
you're not getting half the expression of what's going on.
So I think you are better at what you're doing now
because of those experiences in the cockpit.
I would agree to you.
What I was trying to do is rebase line that I'm
knowing there and these individuals.
But what were your strengths as a driver?
What are your strengths?
Incredibly calm.
I can talk to you on the radio like we're talking now,
despite racing another car.
So I'm able to take it all in my stride and still drive the car.
It's very felt very natural driving the car.
Never got tangled up in any issues or accidents
who otherwise are very clean through racing, very clean and racing full stop.
So I started the race most of the time as a result of it.
Are you able to race now or run out of time?
I think you're going to say, when I talent, that one.
I would love to.
But time is not on my side.
When I do something, I want to do it really properly.
So it's not just about jumping in the car.
It's about doing a proper job.
And to do that would be a sacrifice to Williams,
to the level where I'm not prepared to make at the moment.
This needs all of my attention and all my care.
And I get to do fun things.
I drove a Formula One car just a few weeks ago, in fact.
So it's not.
Don't feel bad for me.
I've got a brilliant drive.
It was in the OWA.
It was here in the family day.
We got it back out again.
So you've seen how tight the never-route's are here,
but I got to have a go around here.
Do you know what, there is actually a brilliant endurance team
on the board here.
Just imagine you, Jensen, button, James, Matthew.
Who else have we got?
Karun's involved in the Heritage.
We spoke about it.
Where is the three J's?
We're already there.
It's going to Jensen about it.
I think he's very much up for it.
We've got tons.
We've got enough here.
Well, let's talk about your F1 drivers now.
Alex Albon, you've worked with in the longest of the current lineup.
How's he evolved?
Do you feel in the time that you've worked with him?
When I sort of came here in the January last year,
he was, I think he'd been a fifth who have varied it.
Don't underestimate how difficult a time he'd been through
before joining this organization.
And I don't think he quite had the pedestals speak up about what he wanted to speak up about here.
The maturity and how he's evolved is he's become a real leader of the organization
and one that wants this to be successful.
One where he's committed his words, not mine, the best years of a career,
typically.
This is where he wants to spend it.
So he wants it to be successful at the same time.
And it's a large self-belief that he's gained.
I mean, he is excellent.
And he just needed someone to really help him on that journey.
And he's really flourished since then.
I think he changed a lot last year when he's driving.
And you haven't seen the end of that change yet.
In terms of what I mean by that is that there's had a phone call with him a few hours
earlier than this.
But it's about not just where we're not in Q3 and Singapore,
we should have been.
But actually, on top of that, he's all the other items that I know in this package
that's given to Liverpool Trust in that's
make sure we're pushing this forward.
And it's just this continuous drive and growth for us to be better.
You know, you talk about he didn't have the pedestal
when he first came here.
It's interesting because one of the things Red Bull used to say about him
is that he lacked self-confidence.
And you feel he's getting that confidence back now.
One for him, to answer, but my opinion of since I've seen him last year
to wear his today, 100%.
Of course, he outqualified Logan Sargent,
what was it? 37,000 in the races they did together.
Can I ask you about what Franco has done alongside Alex?
How do you feel Alex has reacted to having a faster teammate over these past three races?
Start with Franco, first and foremost, the reason why we put him in the car is
he's part of our academy and I believe in investing in our academy.
It was a surprise to everyone, but if I ask everyone to dig back through his career properly
in the detail that we did, which is why he's here,
you'll see that he never had testing or sometimes not even simulator work
that went with it.
He went wherever finance led him to and when he was in those teams did an incredible job
without any kilometres under his belt.
Couldn't Formula 2 have started really developing in that Formula 2 year,
which is why we rewarded him with the Silverstone drive.
And I was a little bit taken aback how quick he was immediately out the post.
I just went to a rally, it was very relaxed.
He said, yeah, it may never happen again, so I was just enjoying the moment.
In the simulator land, he's the same pace as Alex.
And it's a good simulator so we're able to compare where we are here,
but you're never quite sure if that's going to translate.
So I knew he'd be quick.
What I didn't expect is how quickly he's got up to speed.
I thought it would take him a little few races to be there,
so it would be in the Americas before he picked up.
Where strengths are him personally, is that actually,
Simulta Wilde's described he can take all of this pressure,
but thousands of things that come at you and just deal with it in his stride.
He's never flustered, he's never panicked, he's never overloaded.
He's just give me more, and I can give you more back.
He strikes me as a driver that is kind of meant to be in Formula One.
I'll never forget the first press conference that he came into.
He sort of put his arm on the back of the chair.
I thought he was going to light a cigar and get a drink and we were going to be there for hours.
And every time James, every time I thought he was about to stop talking,
no, no, there was another sentence coming.
He just sort of, this was his first press conference.
He just commanded an audience, really.
He had a team talk for the first time with him in Monza.
And he said, I wish I say, I said, speak for me heart.
Just, you're good at it.
Just talk to people.
And he did.
And there's two things.
I would completely say this.
He was at home.
He had a captive audience of the entire race team that wanted nothing but success for him.
But I did have to break into his dialogue about four minutes in,
because we're going to run out of time.
He loves, could be because he talks in the heart.
There's a lot of it.
But he is at home.
Do you don't get this relaxed very quickly unless you're so confident in what you're able to do?
And he's thankful, incredibly thankful for this opportunity.
And the impact he's had on Alex then, because let's wind it back to Singapore Grand Prix.
Over the world feed, suddenly we get Alex's radio message about
Franco's move into turn one.
And I remember thinking, oh, I must have missed that.
The court is time for what's he doing?
Alex's implication was that he was perhaps being a bit rude.
And then we suddenly saw a replay of it.
No, no, there was room and he made the apex and it was all fine.
And so it just made me think, okay, Alex hasn't had a team make this quick.
And we're sort of, are we seeing?
No, I don't think we are.
So I sort of spent some time with both drivers afterwards and watched it from both camera angles.
If you were Alex, it was actually a dust trail.
What he thought he was is he saw Franco with two wheels lit up, completely locked up,
going into turn one.
And before watching that through, you turn right, because that's coming at you,
simple as that.
And I think Carlos did the same thing for that matter as well.
It was not luck, that's dust.
And Franco was completely in control of a car and well done to him.
He properly took that to the limit.
But I kind of get why Alex in the moment thought that it was an aggressive move.
It's also why you heard him afterwards.
You were actually, I've looked at it and it's fine.
It's just, there's a cascade of cars that were getting out the way and I got caught up in it.
But what I like about Franco is he's unfazed.
He was unfazed afterwards.
He's like, man, it was okay.
Just the coolest kid in the world.
And was everything good between the two drivers?
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
In the room, absolutely fine.
And do you think Alex will have to dig deeper again when Carlos science comes here next year?
Yes, but he'll step up to the challenge every time.
That's why I've signed him for a long time.
He's brilliant at this.
So answering a question is he's feeling the pressure now.
He's frustrated because for all of us, he wanted a result and we had a result there.
That's where it stemmed from more than anything else.
But what you will see is in Alex that keeps stepping forward.
Because when you have a team that goes,
I, they found half a tenth there.
I'll do the same.
You start getting pushed in a way that you haven't before.
But his response will only be positive.
So that's Alex.
We've talked a little bit about Franco, but I did want to ask you.
I mean, hindsight is always 2020, of course it is.
You've already said that he was very impressive when he did FP1 at Silverstone.
Why didn't you put him in the car to race after that?
The main priority I had for the team was not who was driving it.
It was making sure we delivered a car at the correct performance level.
Worthy of Alex and Worthy of any else who have been in the seat,
where he can deliver points.
